title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: function evsim package necessary simulate new EV sessions function simulate_sessions(), returns tibble EV charging sessions. required input arguments run function : EV model (object class evmodel) Number daily sessions time-cycle model Charging powers shares relative number daily sessions Dates simulate

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: Package evsim provides EV model example, model created California ACN data California article evprof documentation. model can accessed loading evsim package following function: Let’s take look information print function shows evmodel object: 2 different time-cycles case (Workdays Weekends), one corresponding user profiles. time, user profile time-cycle modeled two different models: Connection Models: combination multiple Gaussian distributions two variables (Connection Start Time Connection Duration) Energy Models: combination multiple Gaussian distributions one variable (Energy) Moreover, User profile corresponding ratio total number daily sessions. example Workday time-cycle see following user profiles components: can modify ratios user profiles one time-cycle function update_profiles_ratios(). new ratios specified tibble variables time_cycle, profile ratio. mandatory time-cycles appear new_ratios tibble, single time-cycle user profiles must appear. example, let’s say want change Workday ratios following ones: , can modify evmodelobject : Note, set Dinner profile’s ratio 0. equivalent discard user profile simulation. directly remove profile model object, set argument discard = TRUE update_profiles_ratios() function.
code: ev_model <- evsim::california_ev_model print(ev_model) ## EV sessions model of class "evprof", created on 2023-01-28  ## Timezone of the model: America/Los_Angeles  ## The Gaussian Mixture Models of EV user profiles are built in: ##   - Connection Models: logarithmic scale ##   - Energy Models: logarithmic scale ##  ## Model composed by 2 time-cycles: ##   1. Workday: ##      Months = 1-12, Week days = 1-2 ##      User profiles = Visit, Worktime ##   2. Weekend: ##      Months = 1-12, Week days = 6-7 ##      User profiles = Visit workday_models <- ev_model$models$user_profiles[[1]] workday_models ## # A tibble: 2 × 4 ##   profile  ratio connection_models energy_models    ##   <chr>    <dbl> <list>            <list>           ## 1 Visit    0.519 <tibble [4 × 3]>  <tibble [1 × 2]> ## 2 Worktime 0.481 <tibble [3 × 3]>  <tibble [1 × 2]> new_ratios <- tibble(   time_cycle = rep('Workday', 2),   profile = workday_models$profile,   ratio = c(0.2, 0.8) )  new_ratios ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   time_cycle profile  ratio ##   <chr>      <chr>    <dbl> ## 1 Workday    Visit      0.2 ## 2 Workday    Worktime   0.8 new_ev_model <- update_profiles_ratios(ev_model, new_ratios)  new_ev_model$models$user_profiles[[1]] ## # A tibble: 2 × 4 ##   profile  ratio connection_models energy_models    ##   <chr>    <dbl> <list>            <list>           ## 1 Visit      0.2 <tibble [4 × 3]>  <tibble [1 × 2]> ## 2 Worktime   0.8 <tibble [3 × 3]>  <tibble [1 × 2]>

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: set number sessions per day function simulate_sessions() function need pass tibble variables time_cycle (names corresponding evmodel$models$time_cycle) n_sessions (number daily sessions per day time-cycle model). example:
code: sessions_day <- tibble(   time_cycle = ev_model$models$time_cycle,   n_sessions = c(150, 50) ) sessions_day ## # A tibble: 2 × 2 ##   time_cycle n_sessions ##   <chr>           <dbl> ## 1 Workday           150 ## 2 Weekend            50

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: also need specify ratio charging power rate, tibble variables power ratio. public charging infrastructure common standard power rates : 3.7 kW AC 7.3 kW AC 11 kW AC set following charging power distribution:
code: charging_powers <- tibble(   power = c(3.7, 7.3, 11),   ratio = c(0.2, 0.4, 0.4) ) charging_powers ## # A tibble: 3 × 2 ##   power ratio ##   <dbl> <dbl> ## 1   3.7   0.2 ## 2   7.3   0.4 ## 3  11     0.4

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: function simulate_sessions() automatically selects time-cycle fits specific date. pass vector dates want simulate. example: Another datetime argument simulation function needs time resolution datetime variables sessions (connection start, connection end, charging end, …). example set time resolution 15 minutes, argument resolution = 15.

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: now required data ready simulate new sessions: obtained total 1674 sessions 7 simulation dates, session corresponding specific charging profile. can notice datetime variables resolution 15 minutes according configuration, energy required corresponds product Power ChargingHours.
code: sessions_estimated <- simulate_sessions(   new_ev_model,   sessions_day,    charging_powers,   dates_sim,   resolution = 15 )  head(sessions_estimated) ## # A tibble: 6 × 11 ##   Session Timecycle Profile  ConnectionStartDateTime ConnectionEndDateTime ##   <chr>   <chr>     <chr>    <dttm>                  <dttm>                ## 1 S1      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:15:00     2019-09-10 15:15:00   ## 2 S2      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:30:00     2019-09-10 16:24:00   ## 3 S3      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:30:00     2019-09-10 16:33:00   ## 4 S4      Workday   Visit    2019-09-10 05:45:00     2019-09-10 11:32:00   ## 5 S5      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:45:00     2019-09-10 15:52:00   ## 6 S6      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:45:00     2019-09-10 15:46:00   ## # … with 6 more variables: ChargingStartDateTime <dttm>, ## #   ChargingEndDateTime <dttm>, Power <dbl>, Energy <dbl>, ## #   ConnectionHours <dbl>, ChargingHours <dbl>

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: Finally, can calculate estimated demand function get_demand(). function accepts optional argument, dttm_seq, datetime sequence time-series demand data frame returned function. set datetime sequence first last date resolution 15 minutes timezone original model (using lubridate::with_tz() function): plot estimated demand (making use {dygraphs} package custom package {dutils}):
code: dttm_seq <- seq.POSIXt(   from = as.POSIXct('2019-09-10'),    to = as.POSIXct('2019-09-16'),    by = '15 min' ) %>%    lubridate::with_tz(     new_ev_model$metadata$tzone   ) estimated_demand <- sessions_estimated %>%    get_demand(dttm_seq)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Marc Cañigueral. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cañigueral M (2023). evsim: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/mcanigueral/evsim/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {evsim: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation},   author = {Marc Cañigueral},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/mcanigueral/evsim/}, }

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: {evsim} part suite packages analyse, model simulate charging behavior electric vehicle users: {evprof}: Electric Vehicle PROFiling {evsim}: Electric Vehicle SIMulation {evsim} package provides functions : Simulating new EV sessions based Gaussian Mixture Models created package {evprof} Calculating power demand data set EV sessions specific time resolution Calculating occupancy (number vehicles connected) specific time resolution Including EV model inputs Shiny Dashboard (Shiny module provided)

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: data set EV charging sessions already built EV model {evprof}, best place start Get started chapter package website.

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: Since package yet CRAN, can install development version {evsim} GitHub:

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: encounter clear bug, please open issue minimal reproducible example GitHub. questions discussion, please send mail marc.canigueral@udg.edu. technical details, can read following academic articles methodology used paper: Electric vehicle user profiles aggregated flexibility planning. IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Europe (ISGT Europe). IEEE, Oct. 18, 2021. DOI: 10.1109/isgteurope52324.2021.9639931. Flexibility management electric vehicles based user profiles: Arnhem case study. International Journal Electrical Power Energy Systems, vol. 133. Elsevier BV, p. 107195, Dec. 2021. DOI: 10.1016/j.ijepes.2021.107195. Potential benefits scheduling electric vehicle sessions limiting charging power. CIRED Porto Workshop 2022: E-mobility power distribution systems. Institution Engineering Technology, 2022. DOI: 10.1049/icp.2022.0744.

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: work developed PhD program University Girona (Catalonia) collaboration Resourcefully, energy transition consulting company based Amsterdam, Netherlands.
